creator: bkorb@gnu.org
text:
# /usr/sbin/httpd -t -f /etc/httpd/httpd.conf
# cat /var/log/httpd/error_log
getpeername: Socket operation on non-socket
getsockname: Socket operation on non-socket
Error getting local address
# uname -a
Linux bach 2.4.19-4GB #1 Fri Sep 13 13:19:15 UTC 2002 i686 unknown

Installation is SuSE 8.1.  1.3.26 came with it.

Did you set "ServerName inetd"?

If so, don't.
creator: slive@apache.org

text:
I didn't touch ServerName, but it has been set.  That must
have been done by SuSE's config stuff.  Can I recommend that
the ``getpeername: Socket operation on non-socket'' message
be augmented by referencing ServerName?  Or even say,
``I cannot resolve xxxxx''.  Some clue.  Meanwhile, its not
clear from the documentation what I should do for my situation:
there is no resolvable name and the IP is reconfigured every
time I restart (dhcp).  I'd be nice to set ServerName to my
current IP, much like dhcp alters resolv.conf?  Thanks for
pointing me in the right direction!!
creator: bkorb@gnu.org

text:
Joshua meant to say "ServerType inetd" instead of instead of "ServerName inetd".

"ServerType Inetd" is appropriate only for running Apache from inetd, and if used
inappropriately it will result in the symptoms you mentioned.

I don't think ServerName has anything to do with your problem.
creator: trawick@apache.org

text:
Thank you!!   Now it works.  *Please* do try to add a reference to
*ServerType* to the message, tho.  Its current form is pretty inscrutable.
I leave it to you-all to decide about status, priority and severity
of this problem report.  To me, this is an incomprehensible error message
bug.  :-)
creator: bkorb@gnu.org
slive@apache.org
text:
Thanks Jeff.  Indeed I meant ServerType.

As far as the error message, those are the messages returned by the OS.
Yes, we could figure out some way to trap these errors and return
something more descriptive.  But in general, if you do something the
docs tell you not to do (set ServerType to Inetd) you can expect
weird things to happen.
